required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: AYActive Study! A Physical Health Activity Intervention
clinical_study.official_title: AYActive Study! A Physical Health Activity Intervention

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this pilot study is to explore the feasibility, acceptability, and efficacy of a 6-week mobile health (mHealth) physical activity intervention among adolescent and young adult (AYA) cancer survivors being treated at the University of Iowa Hospitals and Clinics.

detailed_description.textblock: The purpose of this pilot study is to explore the feasibility, acceptability, and efficacy of a 6-week mobile health (mHealth) physical activity intervention among adolescent and young adult (AYA) cancer survivors being treated at the University of Iowa Hospitals and Clinics. Eligible participants will receive a Fitbit activity monitor and access to the mHealth physical activity intervention for 6 weeks. The intervention will include regular motivational messages to encourage activity, a social media thread to provide social support, and a series of fun virtual walking races. AYA cancer survivors between 13-39 years are invited to participate and the impact of this intervention will be tested over 6 weeks.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: The intervention will include an activity monitor and access to the mHealth physical activity intervention for 6 weeks. The intervention will include regular motivational messages to encourage activity, a social media thread to provide social support, and a series of fun virtual walking races.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of steps taken per day
primary_outcome.time_frame: Dail steps will be measured each day of the intervention for 7 weeks
primary_outcome.description: Number of steps taken per day on each day of the intervention

secondary_outcome.description: Change in fatigue from baseline to post-intervention
Change in pain from baseline to post-intervention
Change in physical function from baseline to post-intervention
Change in anxiety from baseline to post-intervention
Change in self-regulatory efficacy from baseline to post-intervention
Change in social support for exercise from baseline to post-intervention

arm_group.description: Participants will receive a Fitbit activity monitor and access to the mHealth physical activity intervention for 6 weeks. The intervention will include regular motivational messages to encourage activity, a social media thread to provide social support, and a series of fun virtual walking races.

intervention.description: Eligible participants will receive a Fitbit activity monitor and access to our mHealth physical activity intervention for 6 weeks. The intervention will include regular motivational messages to encourage activity, a social media thread to provide social support, and a series of fun virtual walking races.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Male and female cancer survivors
- Diagnosed between 13 and 39 years old
- Currently 3-24 months post-treatment (or in maintenance therapy)
- Receiving survivorship care at HCCC/UIHC
- In remission
- Physically able to walk without limitations
- Own a smartphone with a data plan that is also capable of receiving and sending texts
- Able to understand English and provide informed assent/consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Physically unable to walk without limitations
- Actively receiving cancer treatment
- Does not own a smartphone with a data plan
- Visual or cognitive impairments causing inability to read, complete or sign the consent form and survey
- Participants with diagnosis of thyroid cancer (due to differences in physical, psychological, emotional, and social effects)
- Presence of a psychiatric disorder that is not managed/unstable or suicidal ideation/actuation in preceding 12 months
- Currently meeting physical activity requirements per American Cancer Society guidelines (150 or more minutes per week of moderate to vigorous physical activity)
